Award.AwardTitle: Unraveling Soot Inception in Diffusion Flames with State-of-the-Art Sampling, Conditioning and Analysis Techniques

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Emissions of carbonaceous particles, or soot, are associated with combustion devices that are responsible for more than 80% of the total energy production worldwide. Soot particles released to the atmosphere are harmful to human health and are considered the second largest contributor to radiative forcing in climate change. This project aims at unraveling the mechanisms of soot inception, that is the formation of the smallest soot nuclei that subsequently grow to be responsible for the bulk of the overall soot production in combustion devices. While recent improvements in combustion technologies have reduced soot levels to match current regulations, such improvements have resulted in the release of a larger number of ever smaller particles. As a result, the negative impact of soot emissions remains substantial because small sizes and high toxicity of nano-sized soot particles. It is likely that a fundamental understanding of soot inception will not only be beneficial for current abatement efforts but also for future regulations to limit emissions in terms of number of the smallest and most toxic particles.

In practical settings, soot inception in diffusion flames that tend to be the most common configuration in which sooting conditions prevail. The proposed research takes advantage of purposely developed aerosol sampling, conditioning and analysis techniques to measure concentration, size, charge, and composition of flame generated carbonaceous materials smaller than 2 nm and 3000 Da, regardless of their physical state. The techniques will be adapted to the investigation of diffusion flames of variable maximum temperature stabilized in a novel burner configuration that allows for the necessary spatial resolution. The project will result in the establishment of an infrastructure to study (carbon) nanoparticles and molecular clusters in diffusion flames under well-defined and well-controlled conditions. More broadly, the achievement of this goal will benefit the understanding of the fundamentals of aerosol behavior, including ion collision charging of nanoparticles and molecular clusters. The details about the structure and behavior of soot nuclei provided with the proposed methods will be valuable to improve the predictive capabilities of existing soot models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soot emissions plague most combustion technologies whose dominance in satisfying the global energy demand is projected to persist in the foreseeable future. Predictive models of soot formations are crucial in designing combustion devices with desired performances (e.g., radiative heat transfer) and ever-lower particulate emissions to mitigate air quality and health impacts, aviation contrails, and effects on global climate change. The development of such models is based prevalently on experiments performed in canonical laminar flame configurations yielding to soot formation from vaporized fuels. Canonical laminar flames simplify fluid mechanics but retain all the complexity of the combustion chemistry of fuel pyrolysis and oxidation. Unfortunately, none of the canonical configurations for studying non-premixed combustion existing before the dawn of this project allows for performing the minimally intrusive and spatially resolved measurements necessary to interrogate the soot inception and growth processes using aerosol dilution sampling methods. This limitation has been particularly troublesome since non-premixed conditions are the most common in practical combustion applications, especially those with prevailing sooting conditions (e.g., boilers, diesel engines, gas turbines, stoves, wildfires, etc.).

This project introduced a novel canonical laminar flame configuration, named Planar Mixing Layer Flame (PMLF), for studying combustion chemistry and soot formation in non-premixed conditions. The attached image shows a picture of a PMLF side to side to its fields of temperature and streamlines, as predicted by two-dimensional computational fluid mechanic modeling accounting for detailed chemistry. The PMLF has the structure of a reactive boundary layer thicker than ten millimeters across most of its stable region and keeps thickening at increasing Heights Above the Buner (HABs). Also, the PMLF characteristic advection residence times are of the order of tens of milliseconds, as typical in many combustion applications. Importantly, the boundary layer structure is unaffected by downstream perturbations (e.g., by a bulky aerosol dilution sampling probe) so that intrusive probes cause minimal perturbation of the flame structure and can achieve the desired spatial resolution when used in the PMLF. The results demonstrated the one-dimensional (1D) self-similar structure of the PMLF horizontal cross-section that can be modeled easily, even when accounting for extremely detailed chemistry, using any software package developed for modeling 1D Counterflow Flames among the many of widespread use in the combustion community. The results of sampling measurements performed in the context of this project quantified the fields of 45 gaseous species in two PMLF at different maximum temperatures, including those of key soot precursors such as Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) composed of up to 5 rings and the soot size distribution function. The generated database is a challenging testbed for improving chemical kinetic models, that has attracted so much interest in the combustion community for the PMLF to be selected as the new target for modeling efforts by the community at the last International Sooting Flame workshop in July 2024.  Another objective of the project involved the development of theoretical and experimental techniques to enhance the performances of a few aerosol diagnostics such as High-Resolution Differential Mobility, Atmospheric Pressure interface Time of Flight mass spectrometry, nanometric Condensation Particle Counting, to pave the way to their adaptation for usage in the PMLF. Additionally, the project involved developing and applying optical diagnostics to verify the achievement of spatially resolved and artifact-free results when using methods based on intrusive aerosol dilution sampling.

The results of this project have been disseminated with the publication of a dedicated book chapter and six peer-reviewed articles, plus four additional manuscripts that are either under review or being finalized for submission to the peer review process. Meanwhile, the project supported the training in performing scientific research of 5 graduate and 9 undergraduate students, one of each from an underrepresented minority in STEM, and contributed to the preparation of one, successfully defended, PhD dissertation and two honors theses. Moreover, the project sponsored the preparation and delivery of an invited tutorial lecture to educate on the method developed in the context of this project, tens of graduate students attending the 40th annual conference of the American Association of Aerosol Research, in addition to several presentations in seminars, workshops, and technical meetings and conference of both national and international interest, some of which entailed the preparation of manuscripts for their proceedings. Finally, the project enabled the development of the course titled “Physics of Fluids and Aerosol at the Nanoscale” offered at the University of Connecticut in Fall 2021 and Spring 2024 and completed by 13 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students who provided extremely positive feedback.
